Comment: It’s because he appeals to their basest emotions. His speeches, while lacking in substance, are 100% emotion. He frames their problems with stark black/white storybook simplicity so their brain cells aren’t taxed too much. He stresses over and over again, in the simplest of terms, that he’s going to magically solve all their problems without giving the details of any solution. Frankly, I don’t think they want to hear about the intricacies of statecraft. They worship him because they desperately want to believe that all their struggles can be solved by the star of The Apprentice, despite all contradictory evidence on the ground. They’ve already committed their faith to him this far; they have sunk too much in emotional cost for them to question him at this point.

Comment: Thank you for articulating this point. The followers tend to fall into a specific category: hopeless, poor, (mostly) white people that have felt forgotten. They are the ones that think the country, and democrats, are giving away everything to everyone BUT them. While the democrats can be blamed for more city/suburban focus, their overall policies are solid. They just can’t get the messaging right it appears. Mostly because the followers want someone to save them. They want to blame others for their lot in life and take no responsibility for it, and expect the government to fix it all for them that have been neglected and forgotten, and given their fair due. But they also expect to not pay more taxes, have smaller government, and still get all the things they currently rely on. But when they see rich people being pushed into their face 24/7 on every platform, they expect that to happen to them through their savour, Donald Trump.   Supporters follow along as long as their goals are the same. When they don’t, supporters peace out.
